messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Elliotte Rusty Harold
> Sent: Tuesday, September 27, 2005 7:54 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] JUnit4: TestListener questions
>
> I'm implementing a sample TestListener. I've encountered a number of
> unclear points I wanted to ask about. Here's the interface:
>
> package org.junit.runner;
>
> import java.lang.reflect.Method;
>
>
> public interface TestListener {
>
> void testRunStarted(int testCount);
>
> void testRunFinished(Runner runner); //TODO: Something
> is wrong here...
> Should take an event anyway
>
> void testStarted(Object test, String name);
>
> void testFinished(Object test, String name);
>
> void testFailure(Failure failure);
>
> void testIgnored(Method method);
>
> }
>
>
> 1. What is the first argument passed to the testStarted and
> testFinished
> class? I assume this is the actual test object which in JUnit 4 can
> extend any class. Is it really helpful to pass this given
> that it's only
> an object of unspecified type and in practice may have any type?
>
> 2. Why does testIgnored() get a Method when testFailure gets
> a Failure?
> Should there be an Ignored class? Or should testFailure take a method
> instead? These two feel out of sync.
>
> 3. Does testFinished always bracket testStarted? i.e. does
> testFailure/testIgnored go in between started and finished or does it
> replace testFinished?

1. The first argument is the test object. I assume that it will be useful,
if only to print with toString(). I don't have any examples where it is
used, though, which makes me suspicious.

2. If a test is marked @Ignored, we don't create the test object at all.
However, we need a way to report the class and method that is being ignored.
Method is a handy collector of those two pieces of information.

3. testFinished() is always called.

We would like to move TestListener to an Event object style:
interface TestListener {
notify(TestEvent event);
}

Or something like that. This makes it easier to extend TestListener in the
future (changes won't break existing code) at the expense of readability
(case logic in listener implemetations).

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
